Award.AwardTitle: Conference: FASEB Mechanisms of mRNA decay; Big Sky, Montana; July 6 - July 11, 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The transfer of information from the genomic DNA to messenger RNA (mRNA) during the process of gene expression provides an important way to control the genes responsible for specific biological processes. Understanding how these processes work normally allows us a means to comprehend how they can change when organisms face alterations in their environment or evolve. Recently, it is clear that mRNA degradation is also an important means for regulating gene expression. Thus, gaining a complete understanding of mRNA degradation mechanisms and its regulation are of critical interest. More recently, the spectacular use of interfering RNA to experimentally degrade specific mRNAs has expanded the applications of understanding mRNA decay mechanisms beyond any expectations. The Federation American Societies for Experimental Biology (FASEB) meeting on mechanisms of mRNA decay from July 6th to 11th 2014 in Big Sky, Montana brings together the leading experts in mRNA decay in animal, fungal, plant, viral, bacterial, and archaeal systems. One of the chief benefits of this 5-day meeting is that it brings together experts who study mRNA degradation using various approaches and organisms, providing the opportunity for cross-fertilization and allowing many parallels between mRNA degradation in pro- and eukaryotes to become evident. Both the size and planned organization of the meeting support junior investigators in the field of RNA degradation. With only 100-150 attendees all being housed in the same venue, and with talks and posters only in the morning and evening, there is expected to be ample time and opportunity for informal interactions between junior and senior attendees. Some of the oral presenters will be selected from submitted abstracts to give junior investigators the opportunity to present their work for critical viewing by the community. In addition, poster sessions will allow others to display their work to stimulate conversations and feedback. There will also be meet-the-expert sessions and opportunities to interact with them more informally during the meeting. All of these aspects are viewed as positive enhancements of the professional development of junior investigators in this field.

The requested funds will be used to reimburse seven speakers for about half their costs some selected from submitted abstracts. Priority for this support will be students, post-docs, early-career independent investigators, and members of underrepresented groups who are members of the US scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 9th FASEB Science Research Conference on “Post-transcriptional control of gene expression: Mechanisms of mRNA decay” was held from July 6th to 11th, 2014 in Big Sky, Montana. Many participants indicated that the meeting was well organized and that more unpublished data was presented than at many other meetings. They also commented that the Big Sky venue was excellent. It offered good facilities for the scientific presentations, but also encouraged informal interactions during meals and the free afternoons.

Nine sessions included nine oral sessions with a total of 58 talks on all aspects of mRNA degradation in many different organisms including Metazoa, Fungi, plants, Trypanosomes, bacteria, archaea, viruses and organelles. The session chairs expertly guided the discussion and maintained speakers on time. The sessions covered, ribonucleases, decapping enzymes, the role of the poly(A) tail and other tails, nonsense-mediated mRNA decay, regulation and regulators of mRNA decay, translation and its effect on mRNA stability, and multi-step degradation pathways. The 58 speakers included 31 invited speakers and 27 speakers selected based on their submitted abstracts. 18 of the speakers and three of the session chairs were female. Exactly half of the speakers had not spoken at the previous three meetings in this series, with most of these having never spoken in this series of meetings. The program also included two poster sessions that presented 36 posters. Both the oral sessions and poster session were very well attended and generated lots of questions and discussions.

110 participants registered for this meeting, which is an almost 20% increase from the previous meeting. Many participants held academic positions, but industry and government agencies were also represented. Participants came mainly from the US and Europe, with a few participants from Asia.

This meeting was generously supported by the US government, commercial, and philanthropic sources. Government support came from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious disease (NIAID), the National Institute of Environmental Health Science (NIEHS) and the National Science Foundation. Philanthropic sources of funding were The March of Dimes and the RNA society.  PTC Therapeutics and Nucleic Acids Research provided support from Commercial sources. Approximately 80% of the funds were used to reimburse invited speakers for part of their registration expenses. We awarded travel awards to increase participation of students and post-docs and awarded two poster prizes for students who presented the best posters. Together these awards consumed approximately 13% of funds. The remainder of the funds was used to provide drinks during coffee breaks and poster sessions

            The participants discussed the needs for future meetings, and there was unanimous support to hold a 10th FASEB SRC on mRNA degradation in 2016. After some discussion a large majority of the participants voted to hold the next meeting in Lisbon, Portugal to maintain this meeting as a popular and effective meeting for researchers in both the US and Europe. In case a meeting in Lisbon is not feasible, participants voted to return to Big Sky as their second choice. Participants decided that the next meeting should be organized by Jeff Coller (Case western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH) with help from Ciaran Codon (Institut de Biologie Physico-Chimique, Paris, France).
